content.description: Start with your left hand on the triangle pinch/sidepull and your right hand on the undercling at the mouth of the little cave. Head up and left. There are more potential for lines on this boulder and the surrounding area!
content.location: From the pullout on the left, just past Waves Wall, and across from the abandoned building, head up the hill on the North side of the road and left about 100 yards until you come across a group of boulders.

content.description: Start on the big jug in the left scoop on the wall, and dyno to a flat jug, without using the good holds out left. This is a elimination dyno. S.W. did the first ascent and rated it V Hard, Mark H. repeated it and called it V8.

This is found on the right-most side of the wall.  Start in an obvious mail slot/slash in the vertical section of the wall.  Pull up onto the wall, and move left on in cut slopers into a dished out, right-facing conner to a rounded, somewhat grainy sloper and a sharp crimp.  Once attained, a nice incut pocket gives some chance for composure before pulling up and over on good but gripping topout holds.  It is very cool and worth the effort.
content.protection: Lots of pads and a spotter, 2 would be even better!

content.description:
Start the same as "

The Wright

" in the slot on the far right side of the wall.  Head straight up the vertical/slab to a shallow, left hand, pocket feature.  Head for the top for glory! It is fun and more challenging than it looks!
Starting on the lowest jug rail, aim up and right along the perfect prow. The crux revolves around a left hand crimp and high feet.
content.protection: A couple pads, the landing is decent.
content.location: From the pullout on the left, just past Waves Wall, and across from the abandoned building. Head uphill and left, the boulder sits below the slab cliff line about 25 yards. It is up and left from Frito Bandito Boulder.

content.description: Start seated/crouching on a crimp rail and slippery, water-polished feet below a vaguely triangular feature capped by a large, rounded sloper on the right end of the wall. Pull on and slap for the sloper, then mantel, and top out the easy slab. This is a one-move wonder, but I thought it was fun.
content.location: It is in the bushes on the far right side of the wall, just left of the completely smooth section.

content.description:
Across US Hwy 6 from the parking for Wave Wall is a right-to-left traverse on dikes. Start with a crux high step to an undercling. End with a step down to a slab/boulder.

It is sunny and convenient for a quick workout on the way home from the slopes.
content.location: This is alongside US Hwy 6, just a mile or so below I-70 and the big quarry.  Park in the large pullout on the upstream side of the uppermost bridge in Clear Creek Canyon, between Tunnel Six and I-70.  The Ripple Wall can be seen across the road and 25 feet up.

content.description:
This is a SDS on the leftmost side of the Waves Wall. Sit with a tree just behind you and to your left on 2 really good, undercling, sidepull things. Bust straight left hand over a small, bulging feature on a few small but positive crimps to jugs and a sometimes sandy topout.

This is well worth it, but it is a good idea to dust off the topout before heading off up the problem.
content.protection: A pad. A spotter would be nice. The landing is very safe.

content.description:
Start on the far right side of the Wave Wall, on the same jug slot as "

The Wright

", but jump right blindly around the corner to a massive bucket. Top out on the easy slab straight up.

Start at the same jug as

Zion

, but dyno right to the ledge. This is pure and definitely harder if you are shorter due to the low feet.

A beta video:

https://youtu.be/8LgARibQVdY

.
content.location:
It uses the same start jug as

Zion

.
